awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Wave transport via eigenchannels of complex media
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT
Unlike line-of-sight propagation in a translucent medium, light transport in an opaque medium is a seemingly random walk that is described by a diffusion process. Common to electronic, acoustic, as well as the electromagnetic waves, most of the incident wave is reflected, and only a small fraction is transmitted via a multitude of partial waves with a broad range of delay times. Counterintuitively, this behavior can be altered by exploiting wave interference. This award supports an experimental and theoretical efforts to investigate the degree, to which one can manipulate input waves in a chip-scale platform, to achieve near-100% transmission or avoid temporal spread of a short pulse. The collaborative program of an experimental group at Yale University and a theoretical group at Missouri University of Science & Technology will train graduate and undergraduate students to conduct interdisciplinary research across the evolving boundaries of multiple fields, including condensed matter physics, optics of complex media, nanotechnology, and computational physics. The cutting-edge research will be incorporated in the curriculum at both participating institutions. This project includes an extensive exchange program with visits by faculty and students, summer internships, design and assembly of optical demonstrations for undergraduate research projects and recruitment activities.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT
The concept of transmission eigenchannels has been a cornerstone of mesoscopic physics but it is also applicable to electromagnetic waves and acoustic waves. Despite of the essential role of the eigenchannels in mesoscopic transport and vast opportunities for optical/acoustic imaging applications, little is known about the intrinsic properties of individual transmission eigenchannels or the time-delay eigenchannels. This collaborative program supports a joint experimental and theoretical studies on the statistical properties of individual eigenchannels, such as their fluctuations and correlations, in a unique on-chip photonic platform that allows both selective coupling of light into a single eigenchannel and direct probe of its spatial structure inside the random medium. Compared to electronic systems, robustness of coherence effects for photons at room temperature makes optical systems ideal for the in-depth fundamental studies of coherent wave transport. The proposed work addresses long-standing questions in mesoscopic physics regarding the nature and statistical properties of individual transmission and time-delay eigenchannels and the roles they play in static and dynamic wave transport. A systematic comparison between the experimental and numerical results will provide key insights into how the eigenchannels are formed, what determines their properties, and whether it is possible to achieve simultaneously spatial and temporal control of wave transmission. The research program will produce a wide range of experimental and numerical data, which will pave the way for the mesoscopic physics community to develop and verify new theoretical models for coherent wave transport. In optics, the fundamental understanding of coherent propagation via eigenchannels will inform a broad range of practical applications, from laser surgery, photovoltaics, imaging in turbid media, to random laser and energy-efficient ambient lighting. The collaborative experimental-theoretical program will train graduate and undergraduate students to conduct interdisciplinary research across the evolving boundaries of multiple fields, including condensed matter physics, optics of complex media, nanotechnology, and computational physics. The cutting-edge research will be incorporated in the curriculum at both participating institutions. The two teams will join force in education outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project between Missouri University of Science and Technology and Yale University has made groundbreaking advances in fundamental understanding and experimental control of how light and other waves travel through complex materials like biological tissue or fog. Imagine trying to shine a flashlight through your hand - the light scatters in all directions, making it difficult to control where the energy goes. The research has developed new methods to shape light waves so one can, for example, deliver energy to specific locations deep inside scattering materials.

The initial breakthrough was the discovery that special waves patterns traveling through disordered materials, so called transmission eigenchannels, exhibit unexpected correlations in their transmission properties. This finding led to the development of a comprehensive theoretical framework for predicting how waves behave in complex materials. Building on this foundation, the research team discovered “deposition eigenchannels” - special wave patterns that can concentrate light at desired depths inside complex scattering media. They demonstrated that light intensity at the target can be enhanced up to six times compared to conventional methods, even when using broadband light (light containing many colors). They also introduced “remission eigenchannels” that significantly improve the ability to detect signals coming from deep inside materials. These capabilities have important implications for medical imaging, phototherapy, and other applications requiring precise energy delivery through tissue.

Another major breakthrough was the first conclusive demonstration of “Anderson localization” of light in three dimensions - a phenomenon predicted over 40 years ago but never definitively observed. This discovery helps explain how waves can become trapped in disordered materials, with implications for both fundamental physics and practical applications in photonics and electronics.

The broader impacts of this work extend across multiple fields:

  • Medical Applications: These techniques could improve non-invasive diagnostic imaging and light-based therapies
  • Telecommunications: Better understanding of wave propagation could lead to improved signal transmission
  • Renewable Energy: More efficient light delivery could enhance solar cells and photocatalysis
  • Education: The project trained students in cutting-edge research methods, preparing them for careers in science and technology

Beyond specific technical achievements, this project has established new fundamental principles for controlling waves in complex media. The mathematical frameworks and experimental techniques developed here provide a foundation for future advances in fields ranging from condensed matter physics, optics, acoustics, biomedical imaging to telecommunications. 

The collaboration has produced multiple high-impact publications in prestigious journals including Nature Physics, Nature Photonics, Physical Review Letters and Proceedings of the National Academy of Scince, while fostering international cooperation between researchers in the United States, France, and Turkey. The developed light scattering demonstration and hands-on experiments have been used to engage middle- and high-school students at the annual outreach events at Missouri S&T. The project has also contributed to training and mentoring the next generation of scientists, with students and researchers continuing on to successful careers in academia and industry.
